Synergetic effect of sodium and sulfur on iron catalysts for CO hydrogenation directly to lower olefins Yitao Liu Investigation Formal analysis Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing a Minjie Xu Formal analysis a Xiaoxu Ding Investigation Formal analysis a Zixu Yang Investigation Writing – review & editing a ⁎ Yi-Fan Han Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration a b ⁎⁎ a State Key Laboratory of Chemical Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology, 130 Meilong Road, Shanghai 200237, China State Key Laboratory of Chemical Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology 130 Meilong Road Shanghai 200237 China State Key Laboratory of Chemical Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology, 130 Meilong Road, Shanghai 200237, China b Engineering Research Center of Advanced Functional Material Manufacturing of Ministry of Education, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou 450001, China Engineering Research Center of Advanced Functional Material Manufacturing of Ministry of Education, Zhengzhou University Zhengzhou 450001 China Engineering Research Center of Advanced Functional Material Manufacturing of Ministry of Education, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou, 450001, China ⁎ Corresponding author. ⁎⁎ Corresponding author at: State Key Laboratory of Chemical Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology, 130 Meilong Road, Shanghai 200237, China. State Key Laboratory of Chemical Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology 130 Meilong Road Shanghai 200237 China Iron-based catalysts have recognized as the promising candidates for syngas conversion to value-added products. Sodium and sulfur are widely used to refrain the product distribution towards lower olefins. Herein, the synergetic effect between Na and S were investigated by modulating χ-Fe5C2 with Na and/or S. With the characterization of XRD, Raman spectra, FESEM, TEM, TPD, XPS and semi-quantification calculations, we have revealed that when Na and S are added simultaneously, Na tends to activate the deactivated iron sites by S through electron transfer while the formation of long-chain products were weakened. We also demonstrated that sequential loading Na and S would not result in such synergetic effect because of the overlarge intimacy between both elements. This work emphasizes the significance of the synergetic effect of muti-promotors in such a kind of heterogenous catalysis. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords CO Hydrogenation Lower olefins Sulfur Sodium Synergetic effect 1 Introduction Lower olefins are essential blocks for the production of bulk and fine chemicals ranging from poly-olefins to cosmetics, detergents, lubrican t[1]. Therefore, the supply of the olefin directly affects the entire chemical industry [2,3]. In recent years, in order to alleviate the dependence on petroleum resources, researches mainly focus on non-petroleum routes, that is, the direct or indirect preparation of olefins from fossil resources such as coal, natural gas, and biomass [4–6]. Syngas to lower olefins (STO) has attracted intensive attentions from both academic and industrial corporation due to its lower energy input, water consumption and capital investment [7–11]. Iron-based catalysts have recognized as the promising candidates for STO because of relative cheap price, poison-resistance, high selectivity to olefins and flexibility to a wide range of H2/CO ratios [1,2,12–14]. Studies have been dedicated in improving the selectivity to lower olefins by the engineering of promotors and supports [8,15–17]. Specific to promotors, alkali metals, like sodium (Na), are extensively applied as the electron donor to improve the adsorption/dissociation of CO and boost olefin selectivity by alleviating the secondary hydrogenation. Zhai et al. has reported that Na not only accelerates alkene desorption on the catalyst surface, but also suppresses the secondary hydrogenation of alkenes [14]. Similarly, Cheng at al. has demonstrated that Na affects both the chain growth and olefin secondary hydrogenation, while for longer chain hydrocarbons the effect of Na could be mostly relevant to the suppression of the secondary hydrogenation of the olefins [18]. Torres Galvis et al. claimed that Na reduced methane selectivity by increasing the chain growth probability [19]. However, it is reported that the addition of Na could also contribute to more long-chain products and extra Na would result in a detrimental effect on catalytic activity while favoring the formation of carbon deposits due to the enhanced CO dissociation and carbon coupling ability [17,19]. Sulfur (S) is widely deemed as a poison for iron-based catalysts. Too much of added S compounds often cause catalyst poisoning [20], while small amounts of added S compounds may have beneficial effect [17]. It is reported that a small amount of S addition could obviously enhance the selectivity to lower olefins from 18.7 % to 30.9 %, while the addition of excess S can deactivate the catalyst completely [21]. Yang et al. suggested that S facilitated the formation of more active species of Fe5C2 by suppressing the relative oxidation cycle of iron and enhancing the insertion of carbon that formed from the intermediate’s dissociation into iron atoms [15]. Zhou et al. proposed that an appropriate amount of S could not only enhanced activity and selectivity toward lower olefins, but also increased resistance against carbon deposits [22]. Pioneer studies have investigated Na/S co-promoted iron catalysts for STO [15,17,19,23]. However, most studies focus on the individual role of Na or S, lacking knowledge of the interplay of Na and S on such a kind of heterogenous catalysis. In the present study, we dedicate in conducting comprehensive investigation of Na/S promoted iron catalysts for STO. Especially, with careful semi-quantification calculations and experimental design, the synergetic effect between Na and S is revealed. Those results will inspire creative design novel catalysts for syngas conversion. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation 2.1.1 Preparation of Fe2O3 Fe2O3 was synthesized by a modified hydrothermal method previously reported [24]. Briefly, 4.646 g Fe(NO3)3•9H2O (Macklin, 99.99 %) was dissolved in 40 mL deionized water to form a uniform solution. 40 mL 25 % NH3·H2O (Aladding, 99.99 %) was added to the solution above with vigorous stirring to form a homogenous mixture. After stirring for 40 min, the mixture was transferred into a Teflon lined stainless-steel autoclave (100 mL). The autoclave was heated to 160 ℃ and maintained for 12 h, and then cooled down to room temperature naturally. Then, the resulting solids were recovered by filtration and washed with deionized water. Finally, the solids were dried under vacuum at 60 °C for overnight to afford Fe2O3. 2.1.2 Preparation of sulfur/sodium modified Fe2O3 S and/or Na modified Fe2O3 precursors were prepared by the incipient wetness impregnation method. Typically, Na promoted Fe2O3 was prepared as follows. 0.023 g Na2CO3 (Labor, 99.8 + %) was dissolved by 800 μL deionized water. Subsequently, the above solution was added drop by drop to 1.000 g Fe2O3 made above under simultaneous stirring until the required pore volume of Fe2O3 powder was attained. The resulting precipitates aged under stagnant air at room temperature for about 12 h, then filtrated and dried under vacuum at 60 °C for overnight. The dried mixture was grinded, calcinated in a muffle furnace at 450 °C for 4 h with a ramping rate of 2 °C/min, and then cooled to room temperature to afford final solid and denoted as Na2CO3-Fe2O3. S promoted and S/Na co-promoted Fe2O3 were prepared by substituting 0.023 g Na2CO3 with 0.060 g FeSO4•7H2O and 0.027 g Na2SO3 while keep the other unchanged, and the precursors were denoted as S-Fe2O3 and Na2SO3-Fe2O3, respectively. For the illustration of the synergetic effect of S and Na, we also prepared Na-S-Fe2O3 and S-Na-Fe2O3 by manipulating the loading order of FeSO4•7 H2O and Na2CO3. Na-S-Fe2O3 was obtained by loading Na2CO3 followed by FeSO4•7H2O while S-Na/Fe2O3 was obtained by loading FeSO4•7H2O followed by Na2CO3. It should be noted that the nominal content of Na in all precursors mentioned above were 1 wt% and the mole ratio of Na/S was 2. 0.4 %Na2CO3-χ-Fe5C2, 1.6 %Na2CO3-χ-Fe5C2, 0.2 %S-χ-Fe5C2 and 0.4 %S-χ-Fe5C2 were prepared with the same procedure by loading 0.011 g Na2CO3, 0.035 g Na2CO3, 0.018 g FeSO4•7H2O and 0.031 g FeSO4•7H2O, respectively. 2.2 Catalytic performance The CO hydrogenation reaction was performed in a stainless steel fixed-bed reactor with a 6 mm inner diameter tube inside. 100 mg catalyst was loaded, and activated by a gas mixture of 5 % H2/5 % CO/90 % N2 (30 mL/min) at ambient pressure, 350 °C with a ramping rate of 5 °C/min and hold for 5 h. Then, the reactor was cooled to 150 °C in an Ar flow and pressurized by a syngas mixture (45 %H2/45 %CO/10 %N2, where N2 is the internal standard) to 2.0 MPa. Subsequently, the reactor was heated to 280 °C at 1 ℃/min for the catalytic evaluation. Products were analyzed on-line by a gas chromatograph (Shanghai Ruimin GC2060). CO and CO2 were separated and analyzed by a packed stainless-steel column (TDX-01) with a flamed ionization detector (FID) coupled with a methane reformer. A column (5 A molecular sieve) connected with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) was used for the detection of H2 and N2. Hydrocarbons were analyzed by a capillary column (Agilent HP-Plot Q) coupling with an FID. It should be noted that the carbon balances of all catalytic tests were over 98 %. The spent catalysts were passivated at room temperature with 1 vol%O2/N2 before unloading from the reactor to prevent oxidation by air and preserved in a vacuum chamber for further characterization. CO conversion (X CO ) and product selectivity are calculated as Eq. (1-2): (1) X CO = Q in v CO , in − Q out v CO , out Q in v CO , in * 100 % Q in : inflow velocity, mL/ min. Q out : inflow velocity, mL/min. υ CO , in : concentration of CO in the inflow. υ CO , out : concentration of CO in the outflow. Selectivity ( % ) = n C i Σ n C i * 100 % (2). n : carbon number of corresponding products. C i : concentration of corresponding products. It is noted that the selectivity is calculated with the exclusion of CO2. Thus, the selectivity reflects the proportion of individual organic product in the total hydrocarbons. 2.3 Characterization The surface area of catalysts was measured by N2 physical adsorption process using an ASAP 2020 Version 3.02 H instrument at 77.3 K. Prior to the measurement, the samples were degassed at 200 °C for 4 h. The practical element analysis of the catalysts was performed on an Agilent 725 ICP-OES. Prior to the tests, samples were digested in concentrated nitric acid at 120 ℃ for 6 h. Powder X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) spectra were measured at a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer sourced by a monochromatic Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) with a 40 kV accelerating voltage, 40 mA detecting current. The patterns were recorded scanning from 10° to 80° with an interval of 0.02° and a resident time of 0.12 s Raman spectra were recorded at a confocal Raman spectrometer (LabRAM HR, Horiba J.Y.) with a high-grade Leica microscope (long working distance objective 50 ×) and a visible 514.5 nm Ar+ laser. Single-crystal silicon was adopted for the position calibration. The confocal hole was set to 300 mm for all tests. The test conditions for all the samples were set to 200 µm confocal pore size, 20 s exposure time, 1 mW irradiation intensity and attenuated by a factor of 10 to avoid any damage. The scattered light was collected at 180° (back scattering plane) by a CCD array detector (1024 × 256 pixels, 26 mm in size). Temperature-programmed-desorption (TPD) of CO, H2, C3H6 and 1-hexene (C6H12) were performed in a micro fixed-bed reactor (Linkam Scientific Instruments Ltd.) coupled with a mass spectrum detector (MSD) (HPR-20, Hiden Analytical Ltd.). For CO, H2 and C3H6 TPD measurements, 50 mg of spent sample was re-activated by 5 %H2/5 %CO/N2 for 5 h at 350 ℃ with a heating rate of 5 ℃/min and then cooled to room temperature in an Ar flow. After exposure to CO, H2 and C3H6 for 1 h, the catalyst was switched to the Ar flow until the baseline of the adsorbate signal in MSD was leveled off. The desorption process was performed by increasing the temperature from 50 ℃ to 800 ℃ at a ramping rate of 10 ℃/min. The desorbed CO, H2 and C3H6 were detected using MS at m/z of 28, 2, 41, respectively. For C6H12 TPD measurements, a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) was applied for the detection of the desorbed C6H12. 50 mg of spent sample was re-activated by 5 %H2/5 %CO/N2 for 5 h at 350 ℃ with a heating rate of 5 ℃/min and then cooled to room temperature in an Ar flow. After C6H12 vapor was introduced into the reactor by bubbling Ar at room temperature for 1 h, the catalyst was switched to the Ar flow until the baseline of the adsorbate signal in TCD was leveled off. The desorption process was performed by increasing the temperature from 50 ℃ to 800 ℃ at a ramping rate of 10 ℃/min. X-ray photo-electron spectroscopy (XPS) characterization was conducted in a SPECS spectrometer sourced by an Al Kα monochromatized line of 1486.6 eV. The spent catalysts were transferred to the measurement chamber under vacuum environment. The C 1 s peak at 284.8 eV was adopted as the referent for binding energy (B.E.) correction. The Shirley model was applied for background subtraction due to inelastic processes. Field emission scanning electron microcopy (FESEM) images were collected at a Gemini-SEM 500 at 3.00 kV. Transmission electron microscope (TEM) images and EDX mapping were captured at a FEI Tecnai G2 with 200 kV accelerating voltage. After grinding and ultrasonic dispersing in anhydrous ethanol, few drops of the slurry were dripped on ultrathin carbon film coated copper grids and dried under an infrared lamp prior to the measurement. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physicochemical properties and phase of as-synthesized precursors Diffraction peaks at 24.1°, 33.2°, 35.6°, 49.5°, 54.1°, corresponding to the planes (0 1 2), (1 0 4), (1 1 0), (0 2 4), (1 1 6) of α-Fe2O3, respectively, are observed in the XRD patterns ( Fig. 1 a). Consistent with the XRD results, Raman spectra of the as-synthesized catalysts (Fig. 1 b) also confirms the α-Fe2O3 phase with the peaks of Raman shift at 225, 295, 406 and 1320 cm−1, respectively [25]. Consequently, we infer that the addition of S/Na could not change the phase of the as-synthesized precursors of catalysts. FESEM images shows that the as-synthesized α-Fe2O3 exhibits a compact aggregation of elliptical spheres ( Fig. 2a) with an average particle size of 36 nm (Fig. 2 b). Elemental compositions of the as-synthesized precursors are summarized in Table S1. The weight content of Na in all the samples with the addition of Na is at about 1 wt% while the mole ratio of Na to S is about 2 in the samples with the co-addition of Na and S, namely Na2SO3-Fe2O3, Na-S-Fe2O3 and S-Na-Fe2O3. N2 physical adsorption results (Table S2) indicate that the surface area of Fe2O3 is about 20 m2/g, with a pore volume of 0.14 cm3/g, a pore size of 28.6 nm. With the addition of Na and/or S, the surface area is decreased to about 14 m2/g. This could be ascribed to the coverage of the surfaces of Fe2O3 particles by Na and S. The pore volume of the modified samples almost keeps unchanged. The pore size of the modified samples is enlarged into about 36 nm, which is reasonable considering the loss of the surface area. 3.2 Properties of spent catalysts As can be seen in Table S3, the mole ratio of Na/S remains at ca. 2.0 after reaction, confirming that the promotors are kept well under reaction condition. It is also noticed that the contents of Fe, Na and S are increased after reaction compared with that of the fresh catalysts. This is mainly attributed to the phase transformation of Fe2O3 into χ-Fe5C2. As shown in Fig. 3 a, all spent catalysts exhibit corresponding peaks to χ-Fe5C2. According to the XPS results, typical spectra of FeCx/FeOx were observed with spin-coupled doublets for Fe2p3/2 and Fe2p1/2 at ca. 707.9/709.8 and 720.9/722.8 eV, respectively (Fig. 3 b-f). The appearances of the peaks of FeCx are consistent with the observation in XRD patterns. The existence of FeOx is due to the passivation process with 1 % O2 before unloading the spent catalysts from the reactor. It also should be noted that the binding energy (BE) of Fe2p3/2 and Fe2p1/2 for the Na/S promoted catalysts (Fig. 3 c-f) decreases to 707.3/720.3 eV compared to that of un-promoted χ-Fe5C2 with BEs of 707.9/720.9 eV (Fig. 3 b). BE of Na1s increases to about 1072.0 eV compared with the standard value of 1071.5 eV [26] (Fig. S1). Na is widely employed as the electron donor to improve olefin selectivity in CO/CO2 hydrogenation [14,18,19,27,28]. The addition of Na increases the electron density of Fe, contributing the downshift of BE. It is also noticed that the valence state of Na and S are Na (+1) and S (+6) given the 1072.0 eV biding energy of Na 1 s (Fig. S1) and 169.2 eV biding energy of S 2p (Fig. S2). TEM images were taken to examine the morphology and element distribution of the spent catalysts. EDX elemental mappings results imply that Na and S elements are highly dispersed on iron particles ( Fig. 4). High resolution transmission electron microscope (HR-TEM) images demonstrate that the spent catalysts are made up of a χ-Fe5C2 core and an FeOx overlayer distinguished by the red dash lines in Fig. 5. This phenomenon is coincided with the situation that both iron carbide and iron oxide are spotted in XPS results which can be ascribed to the passivation process. However, χ-Fe5C2 is the exclusive phase can be observed in XRD results (Fig. 3 a). This is reasonable since XPS is a surface detection technology while XRD is dedicated in the bulk detection. As revealed by the HR-TEM images, the amorphous FeOx overlayer could not be identified in XRD patterns. 3.3 Catalytic Performance The catalytic activities and product distributions over un-promoted and Na/S promoted catalysts are summarized in Table 1. With the aspect of activity, χ-Fe5C2 and Na2CO3-χ-Fe5C2 present the same level of CO conversion at about 20 %. While Na2SO3-χ-Fe5C2 shows a decreased activity with 13.9 % CO conversion. When Na and S were added separately (namely Na-S-χ-Fe5C2 and S-Na-χ-Fe5C2), CO conversions drop dramatically to about 3 %. The catalyst has almost no activity when only S was added (S-χ-Fe5C2). Since the product selectivity of Fischer-Tropsch synthesis could be affected by CO conversion, CO conversion were controlled at about 3.0 % for the comparison of selectivity over un-promoted and Na/S promoted catalysts ( Table 2). For the selectivity, Na2SO3-χ-Fe5C2 presents the highest C2-C4 olefin selectivity at 60.2 %, followed by Na2CO3-χ-Fe5C2 (53.3 %), Na-S-χ-Fe5C2 (47.1 %), S-Na-χ-Fe5C2 (43.3 %) and χ-Fe5C2 (39.4 %). Olefin/Paraffin ratio for C2-C4 (O/P) displays the same trend as the selectivity to lower olefins with Na2SO3-χ-Fe5C2 exhibiting the highest O/P (7.3) compared with the other catalysts. Apart from the highest selectivity to lower olefins, it can also be seen that Na2SO3-χ-Fe5C2 presents a favorable stability over 50 h reaction (Fig. S3). 3.4 Adsorption/desorption of CO and H2 Considering the adsorption of CO/H2 is a key factor that governing the activity and selectivity of CO hydrogenation [29–32], TPD of CO and H2 were conducted. Two primary desorption peaks of CO appeared in Fig. 6 a, where the desorption peaks at high temperatures are associated with the strongly absorbed CO and the desorption peaks at low temperatures are associated with the weakly absorbed ones. For the un-promoted χ-Fe5C2, the weakly absorbed CO desorbs at 328 ℃ and the strongly absorbed CO desorbs at 605 ℃. In contrast, with the addition of promotors, both of the peaks unshift to about 450 ℃ and 640 ℃. According to frontier orbital theory [33–35], the chemisorption of CO on catalysts surfaces is mainly due to the interaction of 5σ (HOMO) and 2π* (LUMO) orbitals of CO with the d-band of active metal. The electrons donated from Na tend to increases the electron density of d-band of Fe, thus to facilitate the electron transfer from the d-band of Fe to 2π* orbital of CO, leading to a weaker carbon-oxygen bond in CO and the enhanced CO adsorption on the catalyst surface [36,37]. Conversely, as shown in Fig. 6 b, the desorption temperature for H2 decreases from 571 ℃ (χ-Fe5C2) to about 520 ℃ with the addition of promotors. According to Pauli repulsion, H2 adsorption would be attenuated due to the enriched surface electrons with the introduce of Na. To make a deeper analysis on the CO/H2 adsorption behavior of the unpromoted and Na/S promoted catalysts. We made a semi-quantification analysis based on the peak area obtained from Fig. 6 a and Fig. 6 b. As shown with the purple columns in Fig. 6 c, the area of CO desorption for Na2SO3-χ-Fe5C2 is 42.7 % of the area of CO desorption for χ-Fe5C2, along with 47.7 % for Na2CO3-χ-Fe5C2, 16.9 % for Na-S-χ-Fe5C2 and 11.3 % for S-Na-χ-Fe5C2. Similarly, the area of H2 desorption for Na2SO3-χ-Fe5C2 is 29.2 % of the area of H2 desorption for χ-Fe5C2, along with 35.9 % for Na2CO3-χ-Fe5C2, 14.2 % for Na-S-χ-Fe5C2 and 9.6 % for S-Na-χ-Fe5C2. f presents the relative adsorption capacity of CO to H2 and f is calculated as follows: (3) f = relative area of CO adsorption relative area of H 2 consumption Na2SO3-χ-Fe5C2 shows the highest f value of 1.5 along with 1.3 for Na2CO3-χ-Fe5C2, 1.2 for Na-S-χ-Fe5C2 and 1.2 for S-Na-χ-Fe5C2. 3.5 Adsorption/desorption of C3H6 and hexene (C6H12) C3H6- and hexene- (C6H12) TPD were performed to identify the adsorption/desorption of short-chain products and long-chain products. The peak of weakly adsorbed C3H6 is at about 120 ℃ while the strongly adsorbed is at about 450 ℃ ( Fig. 7 a). In line with the Dewar–Chatt–Duncanson model, the adsorption of olefins is described as the interaction between the surface z2 band of the active metal and πσ/πσ * of the olefins [38,39]. We deduce that the variation in olefin adsorption ability in this study is ascribed to the changes in the z2 band of the iron by Na. Peaks at about 285 ℃ are found for the C6H12-TPD profiles (Fig. 7 b). Different from the adsorption strength of the short-chain products, it seems that the addition of Na/S has little effect on the adsorption strength of the long-chain products. To make a deeper analysis on the C3H6 and hexene adsorption behavior of the unpromoted and Na/S promoted catalysts. We also made a semi-quantification analysis based on the peak area obtained from Fig. 7 a and Fig. 7 b. As shown with the purple columns in Fig. 7 c, the area of C3H6 desorption for Na2SO3-χ-Fe5C2 is 75.8 % of χ-Fe5C2, along with 57.6 % for Na2CO3-χ-Fe5C2, 18.2 % for Na-S-χ-Fe5C2 and 15.2 for S-Na-χ-Fe5C2. Similarly, the area of C6H12 desorption for Na2SO3-χ-Fe5C2 is 26.1 % of χ-Fe5C2, along with 80.4 % for Na2CO3-χ-Fe5C2, 10.1 % for Na-S-χ-Fe5C2 and 5.8 for S-Na-χ-Fe5C2. µ presents the relative adsorption capacity of C3H6 to C6H12 and µ is calculated as follows: (4) µ = relative area of C 3 H 6 adsorption relative area of C 6 H 12 consumption Na2SO3-χ-Fe5C2 shows the highest µ value of 2.9 along with 0.7 for Na2CO3-χ-Fe5C2, 1.8 for Na-S-χ-Fe5C2 and 2.6 for S-Na-χ-Fe5C2. 3.6 Effect of sodium addition (1) Effect of sodium addition on un-promoted χ-Fe5C2. As proved by XPS results, Na could serve as the electron donor transferring electrons to iron. In terms of activity, the sole Na promoted catalyst (Na2CO3-χ-Fe5C2) offers the same level of CO conversion (21.8 %) as χ-Fe5C2 (22.1 %). On the one hand, the loading of Na on χ-Fe5C2 may block the active iron sites from adsorption of CO, reducing the activity of CO hydrogenation, given that the surface area of Na2CO3-Fe2O3 (15 m2/g) is lower than that of Fe2O3 (20 m2/g). It was reported that CO hydrogenation activity increased with the addition of Na, passing through a maximum at a Na concentration of 0.81 wt% [14]. When the loading amount of Na is less than 0.81 wt%, the electronic effect of Na dominating, CO adsorption and dissociation are enhanced due to the promoted d-π interaction between CO and iron by charge transferring from Na to Fe. However, when the loading amount of Na is larger than 0.81 wt%, the electronic effect of Na increases negligibly. While an excess of Na would reduce the surface of the catalysts, impairing the activity of CO hydrogenation. Li et al. [40] found the similar phenomenon that the addition of much more Na led to a decrease in the surface area of the as-prepared precursors of catalysts from 39 m2/g to 32 m2/g. They thought that the more Na was introduced, the greater loss was in surface areas, which was coincided with the observation of Yang et al. [41] and Dry and Oosthuizen [42]. This is also consistent with our results (Table S4). On the other hand, as claimed above, the addition of Na could enhance the adsorption/dissociation of CO, which may impose positive effect on CO hydrogenation activity and promote CO conversion by strengthening CO adsorption. Thus, under the balance of these two sides of effects, the overall activity of Na2CO3-χ-Fe5C2 remains the same level compared with that of χ-Fe5C2. In terms of selectivity, the addition of Na (Na2CO3-χ-Fe5C2) enhances the selectivity to lower olefins from 36.0 % to 51.2 %, remarkably reduces the selectivity to CH4 from 27.4 % to 17.9 % but mildly enhances the selectivity to CO2 from 41.0 % to 44.5 % compared with χ-Fe5C2 (Table 1). Loading of Na impaired both the adsorption capacity of CO and H2 as seen in Fig. 6. CO adsorption area of Na2CO3-χ-Fe5C2 decreases to 42.7 % of CO adsorption area of χ-Fe5C2. And the H2 adsorption area of Na2CO3-χ-Fe5C2 decreases to 29.2 % of H2 adsorption area of χ-Fe5C2. It should be noted that the decreasing amplitude of H2 adsorption capacity is more than that of CO adsorption capacity (29.2 % vs. 42.7 %). This is attributed to the enhance of CO adsorption while inhibit of H2 by the addition of Na as evidenced by the upshift of CO desorption and downshift of H2 (Fig. 6 a). The increased CO adsorption and decreased H2 adsorption on the catalyst surface promotes C-C coupling ability while inhibiting hydrogenation ability [43]; thus Na2CO3-χ-Fe5C2 shows a higher C5+ selectivity, a lower CH4 selectivity and a higher carbon chain growth factor α (Fig. 7 d) compared with χ-Fe5C2. In accordance with the STY of C3 = and C6 = (Table 1), Na2CO3-χ-Fe5C2 presents a slightly increased STY of C3 = compared with that of χ-Fe5C2 (9.0 mmolC·gFe–1·h–1 vs. 8.8 mmolC·gFe–1·h–1). While the STY of C6 = almost doubles over Na2CO3-χ-Fe5C2 refers to that of χ-Fe5C2. Thus, it is inferred that the addition of Na on the un-promoted χ-Fe5C2 contributes more to the formations of long chain products compared with the shorts. The addition of Na also impairs the adsorption of C3H6 (Fig. 7 a), along with the weakened H2 adsorption and hydrogenation ability, contributing the improved lower olefin selectivity at 51.2 % for Na2CO3-χ-Fe5C2 compared with χ-Fe5C2. (2) Effect of sodium addition on S-promoted χ-Fe5C2. Compared with ~0 of CO conversion on S-χ-Fe5C2, the addition of Na on S-χ-Fe5C2 enhances activity by promoting CO conversion slightly to 2.5 % (Table 1). This is mainly ascribed to the enhanced CO adsorption/dissociation ability with Na addition. However, this kind of promotion is too weak, we assume that the poisonous effect of S is too severe that Na can hardly take full advantage of its promotion. To sum up, in our case, the addition of Na on the un-promoted catalyst imposes little effect on CO hydrogenation activity while improves the selectivity to lower olefins, C5+ and reduces CH4 selectivity due to the negative effect of Na on reducing surface aera and the positive effect on promoting CO adsorption, inhibiting H2 adsorption and preventing adsorption/hydrogenation of olefins. Nevertheless, Na promotion on S-promoted catalyst is feeble due to the pre-poisonous effect of S. 3.7 Effect of sulfur addition 3.7.1 Effect of sulfur addition on un-promoted χ-Fe5C2 With the addition of S solely, S-χ-Fe5C2 almost loses all activity (Table 1) due to the poisonous effect of S [44]. Sulfur has been widely accepted as a poison by blocking the active sites in CO hydrogenation reaction [36,45–47]. Jiang et al. proposed that the addition of excess S deactivated the catalysts by reducing CO conversion to 2.3 % [21]. Oschatz et al. suggested that S seemed necessary to suppress the formation of long-chain products but apparently needed a certain concentration for effective operation [48]. This is also consistent with our results (Table S4). The step sites are generally accepted as the active site for reactions involving the cleavage of molecular π bonds like CO activation [36,49–51] because the transition state complex can bind to several metal atoms [52,53]. According to density functional theory calculations, the CO dissociation barrier is strongly lowered at step sites, to 1.61 eV [54] from the very high values ranging from 2.28 to 3.80 eV on a terrace site [55]. Böller et al. prepared catalysts with manipulated densities of step sites by Ar+ sputtering and they found that the activity of the sample scales with step density [36]. It is reported that the poisoning is caused in a nonselective way by a closed layer of sulfur atoms is consistent with a local deactivation mechanism [44]. The sulfur layer covered the terraces up to the step edges, accounting for the reduced activity. In our case, the addition of sole S (~0.7 wt% S, Table S1) deactivates catalyst activity completely, CO conversion approaches to ~0. This may be mainly attributed the relative high content of S addition [56]. 3.7.2 Effect of sulfur addition on Na promoted χ-Fe5C2 (Na2CO3-χ-Fe5C2) It can be seen that S can also deactivate Na promoted catalysts since the sole Na promoted catalyst (Na2CO3-χ-Fe5C2) presents a CO conversion at 21.8 %. While after loading of S, CO conversion of Na-S-χ-Fe5C2 shows a poor CO hydrogenation activity (3.1 % CO conversion). This is also attribute to the poisonous effect of S. However, apart from the activity, the addition of S also alters the products selectivity. Compared with Na2CO3-χ-Fe5C2, selectivity to CH4 increases to 24.3 % from 17.9 % and selectivity to C5+ decreases to 16.4 % from 18.7 % (Table 1). Correspondingly, the chain growth factor of Na-S-χ-Fe5C2 decreases to 0.45 compared with 0.53 for Na2CO3-χ-Fe5C2. Xu et al. [57] reported the same trend that with increasing the S/Fe molar ratios in the catalysts from 0 to 0.01, the selectivity toward C5+ hydrocarbons and the chain growth probabilities (α) of the catalysts continuously decreased from 36.7 % to 27.6 % and 0.58–0.48, respectively. Being consistent with our observation that O/P for C2-C4 decreases to 4.5 from 5.1, they also found the decline in the O/P ratio. It is thought that the rise in CH4 selectivity and the drop of both C5+ selectivity and O/P arose from the enhanced hydrogenation ability of the catalyst due to the addition of S [58,59]. The f value represents the relative adsorption capacity of CO and H2, which could affect the H/C on the catalyst surface during the reaction. A higher f indicates a lower H/C, thus a lower probability of the secondary hydrogenation of as-formed olefins. It can be seen from Fig. 6 c and Table 1 that Na2SO3-χ-Fe5C2 showing the highest f (1.5) contributes the highest O/P of C2-C4 (6.5), followed by Na2CO3-χ-Fe5C2 (1.3/5.1), Na-S-χ-Fe5C2 (1.2/4.5) and S-Na-χ-Fe5C2 (1.2/4.2). Correspondingly, it could be inferred that the f value is positively correlated with the O/P of C2-C4 hydrocarbons. Indeed, the addition of S in our case slightly increases H/C on the surface of the catalyst since the f value (Fig. 6 c) decreases to 1.2 for Na-S-χ-Fe5C2 compared with that of Na2CO3-χ-Fe5C2 (1.3), indicating that S decreases the relative adsorption ratio of CO to H2. And the enhances H/C may promote the hydrogenation of the as-generated olefins on the catalyst surfaces to lower the O/P. Conversely, S increases the relative adsorption ratio of C3H6 to C6H12 (µ value) from 0.7 to 1.8 (Fig. 7 c). To some extent, the adsorption area of C3H6 and C6H12 reflects the formation sites of C3H6 and C6H12, which is that the more the adsorption area of C3H6/C6H12, the more the formation site of C3H6/C6H12. The µ value presents the relative adsorption capacity of C3H6 to C6H12, reelecting the relative amount of formation sites for C3H6/C6H12. A higher µ indicates a higher proportion formation site for lighter products (C1-C4) while a lower µ represents a higher proportion formation site for heavier products (C5+). It can be seen from Fig. 7 c and Table 1 that Na2CO3-χ-Fe5C2 showing the lowest µ (0.7) contributes the highest C5+ selectivity (18.7), compared with Na-S-χ-Fe5C2 (1.8/16.4), S-Na-χ-Fe5C2 (2.6/14.0) and Na2CO3-χ-Fe5C2 (2.9/12.8). Correspondingly, it could be inferred that the µ value is negatively correlated with the selectivity of C5+ hydrocarbons. The decline in the active sites of C6H12 by the addition of S is much more than the decline of the formation sites of C3H6. Consequently, we infer that S tends to preferentially inhibit the formation of long chain products compared with the light products. This is consistent with the report that S could block the active site for C-C coupling to reduce the chain length of the products [21]. Therefore, the nature of S in altering products selectivity lies in (1) reducing the relative adsorption ratio of CO to H2 and (2) preferentially inhibiting the formation of heavier products rather than the short ones. In short, S may deactivate the un-promoted catalyst and Na-promoted catalysts due to its poisonous effect through the blocking of the active step sites of catalysts. S also tends to raise methane selectivity, to reduce C5+ selectivity and O/P in virtue of the enhanced hydrogenation ability and selectively blocked active sites of C-C coupling for the formation of long chain products. 3.8 Synergetic effect of Na and S Likely, the poisonous effect of S can be attenuated greatly with the introduce of Na simultaneously. Na2SO3-χ-Fe5C2 shows a CO conversion of 13.9 % (Table 1), which is much higher than that of S-Na-χ-Fe5C2 (2.5 %) and Na-S-χ-Fe5C2 (3.1 %), let alone S-χ-Fe5C2 (~0 %). To the best of our knowledge, it is the first time we report such a synergetic promotional effect on the STO catalysis. The difference among Na2SO3-χ-Fe5C2, S-Na-χ-Fe5C2 and Na-S-χ-Fe5C2 lies in the loading sequence of Na and S. Na2SO3-χ-Fe5C2 was prepared by loading Na and S simultaneously while S-Na-χ-Fe5C2 and Na-S-χ-Fe5C2 were prepared by loading Na and S separately. Thus, it is deduced that the interplay between Na and S may play a significant role. In term of activity, as abovementioned, Na2SO3-χ-Fe5C2 shows a higher CO conversion compared with that of S-Na-χ-Fe5C2 and Na-S-χ-Fe5C2. We have demonstrated that the promotional effects of Na on S-promoted catalyst are feeble due to the pre-poisonous effect of S, and the failure that Na cannot take full advantage of its electronic properties in the discussion of the effect of Na on S-promoted catalysts. However, when Na and S are loaded simultaneously, Na locates closely at S and S-poisoned iron enough to activate part of the deactivated iron sites poisoned by S through electron transfer. Thus, Na2SO3-χ-Fe5C2 shows an enhanced CO conversion. In terms of selectivity, compared with the sole Na promoted χ-Fe5C2 (Na2CO3-χ-Fe5C2), Na2SO3-χ-Fe5C2 shows a higher C2-C4 olefin selectivity and a lower C5+ selectivity. As illustrated in Scheme 1, it is deduced that the addition of S block part of the iron sites and break the consecutive iron sites. Thus, the CxHy intermediates could not bond together to form long-chain products. This point could be confirmed by C3H6- and hexene (C6H12)-TPD experiments. As displayed in Fig. 7 c, C3H6 adsorption area of Na2SO3-χ-Fe5C2 is 75.8 % of that of χ-Fe5C2. However, C6H12 adsorption area of Na2SO3-χ-Fe5C2 is only 26.1 % of χ-Fe5C2. While C6H12 adsorption area of Na2CO3-χ-Fe5C2 is up to 80.4 % of χ-Fe5C2. This indicate that the addition of Na/S has weaker negative impact on the formation sites of C3H6 compared with that of C6H12. This is consistent with the STY of C3 = and C6 = (Table 1). The STY of C3 = (6.7 mmolC·gFe–1·h–1) drops about 30 % over Na2SO3-χ-Fe5C2 compared with that of Na2CO3-χ-Fe5C2 (9.0 mmolC·gFe–1·h–1). While STY of C6 = (0.4 mmolC·gFe–1·h–1) drops even more (70 %) compared with that of Na2CO3-χ-Fe5C2 (1.6 mmolC·gFe–1·h–1). Consequently, it is inferred that S preferentially inhibits the formation of long chain products refers to the shorts, which could mitigate the negative effect of Na facilitate the formation of long chain products. It should be noted that when Na and S were added separately, Na is hard to activate the poisoned iron sites due to the enlarged intimacy between Na and S. As shown in Fig. 6, the adsorption area of CO is at a very lower level for the sequential added Na/S catalysts (Na-S-χ-Fe5C2 and S-Na-χ-Fe5C2). CO adsorption area of Na-S-χ-Fe5C2 and S-Na-χ-Fe5C2 decreased to 16.9 % and 11.3 %, which are much lower than that of Na2CO3-χ-Fe5C2 and Na2SO3-χ-Fe5C2 (42.7 % and 47.7 %) although they have similar surface areas (Table S2). Moreover, the formation sites of olefins are also reduced to a relative low level. C3H6 and C6H12 adsorption areas for Na-S-χ-Fe5C2 and S-Na-χ-Fe5C2 decreased to 18.2 %/10.1 % and 15.2 %/5.8 %, which are much lower than that of Na2CO3-χ-Fe5C2 (57.6 %/80.4 %). Thus, the poisonous effect of S in Na-S-χ-Fe5C2 and S-Na-χ-Fe5C2 still dominates, which accounts for the relatively low CO conversion (3.1 % and 2.5 %). In summary, Na could activate the deactivated iron sites around S through electron transfer. At the same time, S could reduce the selectivity of long-chain products by reducing the adsorption ratio of CO to H2 and by blocking the consecutive iron sites, which account for the formation of heavier hydrocarbons. And, as a result of the synergetic effect between Na and S, Na2SO3-χ-Fe5C2 contributes the highest lower olefin selectivity of 59.4 % at a CO conversion of 13.9 %. It should be noted that the synergetic effect can merely work under the circumstance that Na and S are added synchronously, which could guarantee a close intimacy between Na and S. It could be a way to inspire the design of high-performance catalysts for STO reaction. 4 Conclusions The synergetic effect of Na and S on iron catalysts for CO hydrogenation directly to lower olefins are revealed. Na could act as the electron donor transferring electrons to iron, enhancing the adsorption/dissociation of CO by promote the d-π interactions between CO molecules and iron carbide, inhibiting the adsorption of H2 and olefins, preventing the secondary hydrogenation of the as-formed olefins. Thus, the sole Na promoted catalyst (Na2CO3-χ-Fe5C2) shows an improved olefin selectivity but also an enhanced selectivity to the undesired C5+ products. The sole S promoted catalyst is almost no activity to CO hydrogenation due to the poisonous effect of S by blocking the active sites. When Na and S are introduced simultaneously, Na tends to activate the deactivated iron site by S through electron transfer and S tend to weaken the formation of long-chain products though the regulating of the adsorption of CO/H2 and preferentially reducing the formation site of heavier hydrocarbons by isolating the consecutive iron sites. With the comparative study of Na2SO3-χ-Fe5C2, Na-S-χ-Fe5C2 and S-Na-χ-Fe5C2, we infer that such synergetic effect cannot form if Na and S are added separately because of the overlarge intimacy between Na and S. This work emphasizes the significance of the synergetic effect of muti-promotors and shed light on the design of iron-based catalysts for STO. coredata.dc:description: Iron-based catalysts have recognized as the promising candidates for syngas conversion to value-added products. Sodium and sulfur are widely used to refrain the product distribution towards lower olefins. Herein, the synergetic effect between Na and S were investigated by modulating χ-Fe5C2 with Na and/or S. With the characterization of XRD, Raman spectra, FESEM, TEM, TPD, XPS and semi-quantification calculations, we have revealed that when Na and S are added simultaneously, Na tends to activate the deactivated iron sites by S through electron transfer while the formation of long-chain products were weakened. We also demonstrated that sequential loading Na and S would not result in such synergetic effect because of the overlarge intimacy between both elements. This work emphasizes the significance of the synergetic effect of muti-promotors in such a kind of heterogenous catalysis.
coredata.dc:title: Synergetic effect of sodium and sulfur on iron catalysts for CO hydrogenation directly to lower olefins
